@why.bsky.team is there a "type" flag for messages so they don't show up in normal feeds? looking for a way to post attestations like flagging disinformation

An attestation for flagging disinformation is the exact usecase we have in mind for labels, which is coming soon ( codes nearly done, just have a bit of stuff to ship to get it there).

For now, you abuse some parts of our system and set the reply field to have an invalid root and parent.
we currently don't support arbitrary record types, but thats what you would want to do in the future (define your own record, and write records of that type to your repo).

record.text: Thats great! would love an english version ;)

Shigepon is retrieving Japanese posts to his server. The content of the postings are compared with the stored postings by morphological analysis, and those that are not trending keywords are matched. This allows us to find interesting posts that we have not been able to reach.

record.text:
the key thing here is that the user is in complete control over what their data is, and so as a result has the ability to set any field in that data to whatever they want.
We can validate it when rendering the application, but the client is the authority
Within that you don't necessarily have access to all the rest of the data in the thread, especially if you want to allow for an eventually consistent global state (aka, federation).

WTF @bsky.app! Why are auto-generated posts specifically suppressed?

I have a whole thread I created with original science data updated daily. Lotta enthusiasm from the community.

When I view this quoted post, it WON’T SHOW ME my own replies. I can’t view the 🧵 in the app even tho I want to? WHY?

value.text:
A few years back I coded an algorithm to compute daily surface melt in Antarctica from microwave sat. data. The NSIDC adopted the code but it isn't live yet.

Until then, I created my own "Antarctica Today" app that'll auto-post replies to this thread.

Daily surface melt extent w/ a 1-day lag.
🧪⚒️🌍

record.text: Within that you don't necessarily have access to all the rest of the data in the thread, especially if you want to allow for an eventually consistent global state (aka, federation).

there is not a usecase for the root being different than the parents, but its quite hard to validate that at the point where the user submits the post. The data model of ATP applications is that each users data is in their own 'repository' of data.

record.text: there is not a usecase for the root being different than the parents, but its quite hard to validate that at the point where the user submits the post. The data model of ATP applications is that each users data is in their own 'repository' of data.

If there is a use-case for it and I just don’t see it (entirely possible), then it kinda makes sense, and you just rely on apps to “not mess that up if they don’t wanna break threads.”

(Though it’d still be helpful for BSky-specific SDKs to hide that parameter and just “do the right thing” anyway.)

at that layer, it doesnt make a ton of sense to do validation of Bluesky specific traits. To improve that, we want to have a much more ergonomic 'createPost' endpoint (or something like this) inside the Bluesky namespace, that is more aware of our specific application and the semantics of posts

ATP is able to support any number of different social experiences.
The clunkiness comes from the fact that for now (and we want to improve this) when you create a post, you submit it through the ATP 'createRecord' endpoint, which is generic to any record type.

record.text:
ATP is able to support any number of different social experiences.
The clunkiness comes from the fact that for now (and we want to improve this) when you create a post, you submit it through the ATP 'createRecord' endpoint, which is generic to any record type.

to get very technical here, theres two layers to this application. Bluesky the social network is build on top of the AT Protocol. posts (and likes and follows and such) are defined in the namespace of bluesky, they are specific to our application.

record.text: to get very technical here, theres two layers to this application. Bluesky the social network is build on top of the AT Protocol. posts (and likes and follows and such) are defined in the namespace of bluesky, they are specific to our application.

Or at least, cutting access for the *user* to set “root” to be whatever they feel like it should be, since that’s not what the API needs and it breaks threads if it’s not set just-right. Seems like it’s causing needless issues and can be automated around so it just does the right thing by default.

record.text: For any post that is a reply in a thread, the 'root' must be set to the uri of the root post in that thread, so all replies in a given thread have the same root value.

yeah, somethings funky with how you're setting reply parents and roots. 
This post you linked: bsky.app/profile/did:...

has its parent set correctly, but the root is some other post altogether: (bsky.app/profile/did:...)

value.text:
A few years back I coded an algorithm to compute daily surface melt in Antarctica from microwave sat. data. The NSIDC adopted the code but it isn't live yet.

Until then, I created my own "Antarctica Today" app that'll auto-post replies to this thread.

Daily surface melt extent w/ a 1-day lag.
🧪⚒️🌍

images.alt:
Daily Antarctic surface melt on Sat December 16, 2023.

Image is auto-generated.

record.text:
yeah, somethings funky with how you're setting reply parents and roots. 
This post you linked: bsky.app/profile/did:...

has its parent set correctly, but the root is some other post altogether: (bsky.app/profile/did:...)

I'm using an app (AntarticaToday) & the atproto.blue SDK. If it's simply a bug in the way they're being posted (thread URIs not set correctly, etc), I'd be relieved, because that'd be fixable, rather than an "unspoken policy of BlueSky" suppressing it.
(Hanging up my conspiracy hat, momentarily.)

record.text:
WTF @bsky.app! Why are auto-generated posts specifically suppressed?

I have a whole thread I created with original science data updated daily. Lotta enthusiasm from the community.

When I view this quoted post, it WON’T SHOW ME my own replies. I can’t view the 🧵 in the app even tho I want to? WHY?

High likelihood that the thread uris arent being correctly set. Im at lunch but will take a look soon.
What are you using to create the posts?
Query @pfrazee.com or @why.bsky.team about this. Might be a recent bug.

record.text: honestly, just about anything. If you have a big ham to slice food off of, you probably don't need a microwave
Are there other appliances that we can replace with ham?
i'm still upset about this

value.text: i want a bigger house so i can fit a whole ibérico ham on my counter, where i can slice some of it off for a snack whenever it strikes my fancy

record.text: As a long time arch user I will happily pay that $5.99

macos: mouse settings is a third party app that costs $5.99

windows: mouse settings is a third party app that costs 350MB of disk space

linux: mouse settings is an xorg config file with no wayland equivalent

macos: mouse settings is a third party app that costs $5.99

windows: mouse settings is a third party app that costs 350MB of disk space

linux: mouse settings is an xorg config file with no wayland equivalent
my vim muscle memory is just a series of weird rituals at this point
The longer I work in the tech industry the more I realize engineers are the most superstitious and religious tribe in the world.
The longer I work in the tech industry the more I realize engineers are the most superstitious and religious tribe in the world.
If you have a TV then perhaps consider replacing your TV with ham
i'm still upset about this

so im not 100% sure if this is possible, but i think that if you had the key locally, you could generate a valid auth token offline (cc @dholms.xyz )
that is technically how login works, but its your PDS signing something. the JWT you use for auth is signed by the key associated with your account
i should be able to login to bsky by signing a message

well thats pleasant
I just learned there's a magazine about "the imagination of trees". Isn't that a beautiful phrase? arboretum.harvard.edu/arnoldia/
people ask why i like the pacific northwest — i travel a lot, but i like returning to a place where the trees have a mysterious aura. it’s enchanting.

record.text: Theres not a lot it makes economic sense to use the cloud for... you're now browsing this website via our new on-prem servers

Okay, I've been dancing around it for years--it's time to call it:

There's no economic story around using the cloud for steady-state HPC workloads. It's not even close to cost competitive.

Okay, I've been dancing around it for years--it's time to call it:

There's no economic story around using the cloud for steady-state HPC workloads. It's not even close to cost competitive.
thanks for the heads up! keep 'em coming as you notice things

@why.bsky.team since the team looking for errors with the new deployment. In the last hour or so, I can see posts on my timeline, but clicking on them triggers and "Internal server error" message. For every single post, like this one. bsky.app/profile/kate...

value.text: a thing that I don't know but would like to know — since a judge ruled today that Elon Musk's Tesla compensation is excessive, does that mean he needs to... give the money back? www.nytimes.com/2024/01/30/b...

external.description: Shareholders had sued, arguing that Mr. Musk’s compensation — which helped make him the world’s richest person — was excessive.
